results.firPara: Will Leicester City do themselves proud? Do Celtic have a chance of upsetting Barcelona? And how much will Manchester City improve under Pep Guardiola?
results.secPara: After a few anxious play-off rounds, the Champions League group stage begins on Tuesday. Teams from 17 countries will take part, with Premier League champions Leicester City and Russian Premier League runners-up FC Rostov making their debuts. If your club team has made the last 32, wed like to hear your expectations for the campaign.
results.webTitle: Champions League 2016-17: how far will your club go this season?

results.firPara: Its probably just as well the Manchester derby is happening so early in the season. Theres only so much fevered anticipation, so much guarded politeness, so many unconvincing insistences that they get along fine that a league can take. Certainly, theres only so often it can be pointed out that beating Bournemouth, Southampton and Hull or Sunderland, Stoke and West Ham is all very well but the real test will come in the derby.
results.secPara: So its just as well for narrative purposes – and, really, what else matters in the supercharged soap opera of the modern Premier League? – that the first meeting of José Mourinho and Pep Guardiola since they left Spain should happen in Manchester rather than Beijing, that the first clash scheduled for pre-season should leave no trace beyond an abandoned game and the strange bickering over the size and temperature of the press conference room. If their rivalry is to be apocalyptic, its fitting that their first crossing of Mancunian swords should happen in Manchester and should be meaningful.
results.webTitle: José Mourinho’s faith in Wayne Rooney faces biggest test in Manchester derby | Jonathan Wilson

results.firPara: Crystal Palace fear they will be without their recent signing Loïc Rémy for up to two months after the forward picked up a thigh injury in training and returned to Chelsea for treatment.
results.secPara: Rémy joined Palace at the end of last month, initially on a seasons loan, for a fee of around £3m, with a view to a permanent deal. The latter stages of the 29-year-olds two-season stint at Stamford Bridge were dogged by injuries which cast him to the fringes, with Chelsea prepared to loan him out despite having only Diego Costa and Michy Batshuayi as senior strikers.
results.webTitle: Crystal Palace’s Loïc Rémy out for up to two months after fresh injury blow

results.firPara: Crystal Palace have completed the signing of the former Arsenal and Milan defensive midfielder Mathieu Flamini on a contract until the end of the season.
results.secPara: The 32-year-old Frenchman had been a free agent after being released by the Gunners in the summer after playing 246 times over two spells, including 24 times last season. During his seven seasonswith the club he helped Arsène Wengers men win three FA Cups and reach the 2006 Champions League final.
results.webTitle: Mathieu Flamini joins Crystal Palace on free transfer

results.firPara: The conduct of Charltons owner, Roland Duchâtelet, and chief executive, Katrien Meire, has led to a fracture with many of the clubs fans. But after relegation to League One there are signs of recovery on the pitch
results.secPara: The conduct of Charltons owner, Roland Duchâtelet, and chief executive, Katrien Meire, has led to a fracture with many of the clubs fans. But after relegation to League One there are signs of recovery on the pitch
results.webTitle: Charlton aiming to rise again against backdrop of fury and boycotts | Nick Miller

results.firPara: Wayne Rooney captains four City players, as well as Marcus Rashford, in our composite side and there can be no doubt about the manager
results.secPara: Agree/disagree this is the point of selecting a combined Manchester XI from the City and United squads of Pep Guardiola and José Mourinho to contest Saturdays game. Apart from the goalkeeper, every berth was difficult to decide. The manager, though, proved a no-brainer.
results.webTitle: Who makes our combined United and City XI for the Manchester derby?

results.webTitle: Andy King says Leicester City are on the up and ready for Liverpool

results.firPara: To get an idea of how deep the resentment lies – and Zlatan Ibrahimovic has never been one to go in for superficial niceties – perhaps the best place to start is the interview he gave to CNN last November, as a Paris Saint-Germain player, and his response to the question about what it was like playing for Pep Guardiola. As a coach he was fantastic, Ibrahimovic said. As a person Ive no comments about that, thats something else. Hes not a man, theres nothing more to say.
results.secPara: Alternatively one could flick through the pages of I Am Zlatan Ibrahimovic – a book the Guardians Richard Williams described as the most compelling autobiography ever to appear under a footballers name – and examine some of the lacerating words the Manchester United striker reserves for his former coach at Barcelona. Guardiola is a spineless coward. By the end Ibrahimovic does not even want to use Guardiolas real name. Instead he calls him the Philosopher, with barely disguised contempt.
results.webTitle: Zlatan Ibrahimovic’s contempt for Pep Guardiola burns brightly as derby looms | Daniel Taylor
